title: Virginia Water Lake Walk Route

images.title: Brendan and Ruth McCartney / Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: This Totem Pole is located on the extreme western edge of the square in Virginia Water.

images.title: Colin Smith / Lakeshore at Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lakeshore at Virginia Water. By the Fishing Temple viewpoint on the southern shore of this elongated artificial pond in Windsor Great Park.

images.title: Colin Smith / Boathouse on Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Boathouse on Virginia Water. View across the water in Windsor Great Park towards Temple Bungalow.

images.title: Len Williams / The Obelisk, Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Cumberland Obelisk was erected by King George II in memory of his son Prince William, the Duke of Cumberland. Prince William had been the park ranger and had been instrumental in creating Virginia Water from the original marsh.

images.title: Colin Smith / Reeds on Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Reeds and birches in the spring evening sunshine

images.title: Colin Smith / The Cascade, Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Cascade waterfall by the lake. Scenic point where Virginia Brook flows out of Virginia Water in Windsor Great Park. The falls were constructed in the 18 century, reputedly using stones taken from the site of a Saxon settlement on Bagshot Heath.

images.title: Colin Smith / Corinthian Columns, Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Corinthian Columns. These stones once stood in the Roman city of Leptis Magna which was sited near Tripoli (Libya). The stones were taken and re-erected here in a romantic landscape

images.title: Colin Smith / Roman Ruins, Virginia Water, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Roman Ruins. The Romantic Landscape - using Roman stones from the ruined city of Leptis Magna in Libya.

description: Enjoy a waterside walk around the beautiful Virginia Water in Windsor. The lake is located within the wonderful Windsor Great Park and is surrounded by woodland and gardens. A well defined walking path runs around the lake taking you to a number of interesting sites. You'll pass the 18th century ornamental cascade and the Leptis Magna Ruins - a Roman style temple built from columns and lintels brought from the ancient city of Leptis Magna in the early 19th Century. There is also a striking 100-foot high Totem Pole and the Virginia Water Pavilion built from wood from Windsor Great Forest. Right next to the lake are the stunning Valley Gardens . Here you'll find 250 acres of landscaped gardens and woodlands to explore using a series of well defined walking trails. You could also head further into Windsor Great Park to extend your walk.
